name: methyl 3-chloro-4-methoxybenzoate
Reason: The compound methyl 3-chloro-4-methoxybenzoate has a structure composed of a benzene ring with a methyl group attached to the alpha carbon atom, a chlorine atom attached to the beta carbon atom, and a methoxy group attached to the gamma carbon atom. The chlorine atom increases the melting point due to the increased electronegativity and polarizability of the atom, which increases intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. The methoxy group also increases the melting point due to the increased electronegativity and polarizability of the oxygen atom, as well as the increased hydrogen bonding potential. However, the methyl group may slightly decrease the melting point due to the reduced planarity and potential packing efficiency of the molecule. Starting with a base value for benzene around 80 degrees Celsius (as a rough approximation considering the melting point of toluene at 111 degrees Celsius and accounting for the extra methyl group), the addition of a chlorine atom might introduce an increase of approximately 20 degrees Celsius, due to the increased electronegativity and polarizability of the chlorine atom. The addition of a methoxy group might introduce an increase of approximately 10 degrees Celsius, due to the increased electronegativity and polarizability of the oxygen atom and the increased hydrogen bonding potential. Therefore, the estimated shift would be 80 (base) + 20 (chlorine contributions) + 10 (methoxy contributions).
